description: From a blend of smack +‎ mash. Compare Swedish smask (“a light explosion, crack, report”), dialectal Swedish smaska (“to smack, kiss”), Danish smaske (“to smack with the lips”), Low German smaksen (“to smack with the lips, kiss”).

entries.meaning: The sound of a violent impact; a violent striking together.
examples: I could hear the screech of the brakes, then the horrible smash of cars colliding.
The driver and two passengers were badly injured in the smash.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Something very successful or popular (as music, food, fashion, etc).
examples: This new show is sure to be a smash.

entries.meaning: (tennis) A very hard overhead shot hit sharply downward.
examples: A smash may not be as pretty as a good half volley, but it can still win points.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, archaic) A disaster; a bad situation.
A kind of julep cocktail containing chunks of fresh fruit that can be eaten after finishing the drink.

verbs.description: smash (third-person singular simple present smashes, present participle smashing, simple past and past participle smashed)

examples: The demolition team smashed the buildings to rubble.
The flying rock smashed the window to pieces.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be destroyed by being smashed.
examples: The crockery smashed as it hit the floor.
He smashed his head against the table.
Bonds smashed the ball 467 feet, the second longest home run in the history of the park.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To ruin completely and suddenly.
examples: The news smashed any hopes of a reunion.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To defeat overwhelmingly; to gain a comprehensive success over.
examples: I really smashed that English exam.

entries.meaning: (transitive, US) To deform through continuous pressure.
examples: I slowly smashed the modeling clay flat with the palm of my hand.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang, vulgar) To have sexual intercourse with.
